text:
Just drove the Amalfi cost all the way from Salerno to Agerola. Have to say it’s not a scary or nerve wrecking drive as I was led to believe.
If you drove in a mountain before is pretty similar plus there’s mirrors in the tight curves, tunnels are wide enough for two cars and there’s small viewing points along the road to stop the car and admireआणखी the view.

It’s actually pretty fun to drive with a small car.

Ps: sorry to say but Italians are absolutely terrible drivers, very unconscious driving and they don’t have respect for rules or other drivers. While driving down here always look ahead for buses and other larger vehicles and pull to the side when possible and if necessary and enjoy. The view is breathtaking

comments.comment_text: It's bellissima!
I love the twisty roads vs the boring N.A. roads
And don’t forget, the white line down the center of the road is for motorcycles!
Personally I think the Italians are excellent drivers, they have no fear and understand the rules of their roads also most don't see a car as a prized possession.🤣

text: My husband and I are traveling to Italy late September visiting Venice, Florence and Rome. We plan to travel city to city by train. Friends of ours suggested we wait to buy train tickets until we get there to provide more flexibility to our travel plans, but I am very much a "book as much as you can in advance" type person. Any reasons why we should/shouldn't wait to book, or does it really just boil down to personal preference?

comments.comment_text: For the high speed trains, the prices go up the closer you get to the departure date. Check prices right now as if you need to travel today or tomorrow, then look and see how much the same ticket would be a month or more from now. Another reason to book earlier might be for seat selection, but I'm not familiar with how full the trains get on those popular routes.

I’ve heard it’s good to book in advanced if you’re going during peak tourist season, you’re booking an express train and/or it’s a popular route.

However, I just left Italy and had no problem buying tickets 15 minutes before. This allowed me flexibility to leave earlier/later and caused me less stress that we were going to miss our train.
I've done 3 multi city trips to Italy and don't think I ever booked tickets in advance. I'd say it's just personal preference.
For the high speed trains, if you book early you can get much better seats, with free snacks and prosecco 🥂!
For Frecciarossa (the hight speed train) it’s better buy before because of the prices.
Personal preference I think. I booked my first two journeys in advance.... Then the rest (local trains) the day before
Cheaper to book ahead

Cheaper to book the high speed ahead. I'm the same as you. I need to have the stuff planned that I can. I booked mine 3 months out from our trip. I had to buy six so it also helped to spread my spending out a bit.

I personally like to know most details in advance. I book all hotels/
Airbnbs, tours, trains (only the high speed ones) and even some difficult to get into restaurants in advance. It’s also cheaper to book ahead.
Personal preference but I wanted flexibility when I was there in May. It is so easy to buy train tickets on the Omio app. Can be done the night before planned travel.
I booked a few ahead and it worked out but would’ve been fine to wait! But the pre booked trips helped us plan our day
I’ve never booked train tickets in advance and I’ve been going for years, don’t do peak times before 9:30am & after 4pm you will pay more 🌻
If you are using trains a lot in Europe and want flexibility, you could compare ticket prices with a Eurail pass.
I just did this same trip. I booked in advance.
I accidentally prebooked the wrong date. The day of was double the price. This was from Salerno to Rome.
Be aware that the Ryder Cup is in Rome, Sept 30 through October 2? I think.
That’s really true buy your ticket there in trenitalia frecciarossa in Roma termini get a number they will assist you
You can also buy tickets for business class through Trenitalia on Frecciarisa (a little bit more expensive) that allow for full refund should you change your mind or need to change the time of travel

text: We were on the bus today in ROME and were asked for our tickets by the police who hopped on at one of the stops. Saw someone get fined. Phew, glad we got the 7 day pass and do not have to validate every single time we get on and off transportation 🙂 Best $25 spent!

Hi I'm driving to Italy in August from the UK.

Will I need an international driving permit?

So much mixed info online.

Thanks

comments.comment_text:
I can see its confusing....lo
oking at sites promoting IDP, they generally say you do....however is misleading....t
he official UK Gov site info below shows that if you have photo id uk licence, you do NOT need an IDP for (up to) 90 day tourist visit.

https://
www.gov.uk/
driving-abroad/
international-dr
iving-permit

It's because there are so different nationalities on this site. Americans driving in Europe need an international driver's permit. Can't speak to a British driver's license holder - if that's who you are. You don't say where your license is issued

No, you don't - we do it regularly! Make sure your insurance covers you for EU, and you have breakdown cover, just in case. You should also carry high-vis vests for every passenger, a fire extinguisher, and warning triangle. Carry your paperwork also. In 12 years only been stopped once (by bored Belgian police officers in the middle of the night😅) but you don't want to risk a fine. PM me if you'd like route info!
Best option is always to check official sources.

My husband and I are heading to Italy in April next year amongst other places in Europe from Australia. We will be staying in Naples for two nights before heading to Sorrento to explore the Amalfi coast. I would really like to spend quality time in Sorrento, Positano and possibly Amalfi but would like to see things along the way especially Fiordo di Furore. I’m just wondering how everyone explored the Amalfi coast, I have been looking at day tours that run from either Sorrento or Positano that don’t look to bad for us to see other places such as Ravello. These seem to be our best option money wise, has anyone done it this way? If so recommendations?
We’ll be doing a day tour to Capri from Sorrento and we’ll be doing a day tour to Pompeii from Naples so both of those places are sorted.
I’ve also looked into hiring a car but then I’ve read about how hard the parking is etc so I’m not sure that’s a good option.

This is the first time we’ll be heading to Amalfi Coast so I want to get to most out of it as we tend to try new places each time we travel and probably won’t be back for a long time. We also like to keep things on the cheaper side but open to suggestions.
Thank you for any recommendations and/or advice you have!

comments.comment_text: We have just had a week exploring the Amalfi coast - Positano and Sorrento as bases and then a mix of ferry and local buses for day trips. Fiordo di Furore was excellent as a day trip and easy using the local buses. We hired a car but it was an SUV (as we are a family of four adults) so not ideal for driving the Amalfi!! Check your accommodation offers parking. We loved Positano and Sorrento. We did the day trip to Capri from Sorrento as it’s closer.
Following
Word of advice from a fellow Aussie…. Don’t drive !🙏🏼

You can ferry or boat tour to Capri, Positano and Amalfi. We did a boat tour and liked it because our guide explained things we saw on the way.
When in Sorrento, definitely go to Marina Grande

Get private hire to take you around but it’s too crowded for me. Ravello is the Amalfi gem. See Villa Rufolo. I would only recommend stopping in Ravello and Amalfi to see the cathedral. We used

https://
www.easycartourn
aples.com/

We did a ferry to Capri which was perfect and we did a private boat tour through MBS Blu charter on trip advisor that was 8 ish hours that went to amalfi, positano each for two hours then a private beach to swim for an hour. All from sorrento. Highly recommend the boat tour.

Tours are a good idea there, they pick you up and drop off. Sorrento is a good base, you can ferry from there. Positano also has ferry. Ravello is gorgeous, my favorite. But it’s for after you’ve been there a few times and have seen all the rest and just want to experience it. You can take a ferry to A,Aldi and hike up to Ravello if you like to do that kind of thing.

I stayed in PositAno and loved it. We used the ferries and local bus very easily and went to Sorento, amalfi, ravelo and did a day trip to Pompeii/
vesuvious. Cars are hard because no parking. You can also do a day trip to capri
Get in touch with Taxi Mister Cab Driver-Naples & Amalfi coast- he will plan a perfect day
Following

Stayed in Sorrento. Go to
Amalfi coast towns by ferry or or driver.

Hi from a fellow Aussie who spent 2 nights in Sorrento and 4 nights in Positano!
If we did it again, we would 100% base in Sorrento and do an amazing tour to Capri which we loved sooo much, and a ferry to Positano for a day, as well as any other towns you're keen on.
Sorrento is super affordable, lots to eat and easy to get around from there.. If you're very keen go to Positano for a night or 2 but if you can, spend the money to stay as close to beach as possible. If you can afford it, Luna at Villa Magia for dinner is spectacular!!!
Ferries are easy and busses are ok too, but the roads are crazy and they're busy so we avoided them. In my opinion, the best code of Positano was from the ferry coming in from Sorrento!! Ferry terminal is easy, just make sure you get there 1 hour early 😊
Agreed DO NOT drive! if you need a great transfer driver from Positano I can get our guy's details!

Hi sent u private message just got back from amalfi♥️

4 days on the beach(Bagni SantaAnna) in Sorrento and 1 day excursion to Capri. It was very relaxing 5 days after mad sightseeing in Rome and Venice. 2 hour tour of Pompeii on the way back to Naples train station.
Following

We always drive to positano and stay there then ferry out to other towns. The path of gods is a must do! Sorrento is also a great place to stay for a base then travel via water ferry to neighbouring villages

Also from Aust. 4 weeks ago we stayed in an air bnb in Sorrento. We walked everywhere. Caught the ferry to Positano and the bus back.
Used public transport for other places.

If you can, avoid the week from the 20/4/24 and the one afterwards - there will be 2 Italian bank holidays (25/4 and 1/5) right in the middle of both weeks, so lot of people may decide to spend the weekend or the whole week there

We spent 3 days in Sorrento. We stayed at La Badia hotel which was a quiet hotel with beautiful views and included breakfast. One of the days we took a ferry to Ischia and the other day we went to Bagno Regina Giovanna. Both places I would highly recommend. The other day was a travel day so we just walked around the town.
Taxi Mister is your best bet….Ciro is the greatest!!!

I’m also from Australia and just arrived home. Definitely would not drive. Nowhere to park. We stayed over night in Sorrento. Spent most of our time at Leonelli’s beach. We definitely needed more time in Sorrento as it was amazing!!! We then headed to Praiano where we stayed at the Grand Hotel Tritone for 3 nights. It was one of the highlights of our 4 week trip. They have a jetty so we had organised a private boat day trip through the hotel to Capri on one day (700 euro for 8ppl). The next day we organised a private water taxi to take us to Amalfi (160 euro for 8 ppl each way) and back and then a private water taxi to take us to Positano for dinner (120 euro for 8 ppl one way). Seeing the coastline by the water was magical. We took a taxi back to Praiano at night. Have the best time.
Private car…. Loved it!!!
F
We just left Sorrento and stayed in Marina Grande at the only place directly on the water called ‘la Luella’ and it was heaven!!

There are buses that go from sorrento either a tour bus to Amalfi and positani hop on and off or we got local bus back from.positano. when in amalfi three is a bus to ravello. However I hear a boat or ferry from sorrento around to those is a great way to arrive. They are easily explored alone.

I’ve been to the Amalfi Coast several times. Explored it by public transportation,
which I did not enjoy, ( although the ferries were better than the buses) and by self driving a rental car, which is by far my preference. When using public transportation I stayed in Sorrento. When self driving I’ve stayed in different towns Amalfi , Positano, & Ravello included. My favorite was Ravello.

Things I wish I’d have done differently 1. Spend more time in the smaller less visited but still beautiful towns of Atrani, Praiano, & Minori etc. they’re just as pretty as the more visited towns but have somewhat lower prices and fewer crowds. 2. Stayed for more than two nights in gorgeous Ravello. 3. In general stayed longer everywhere
& not visited any of the towns as a day trip. Because these towns do not show their best face in a short couple of hours. Being in them in the early morning before the day trippers arrive and in the evening and night after they leave is a magical
experience that oozes charm and atmosphere. It’s far different than a quick daytime visit among the hordes.

My husband and I are going to Amalfi Coast in April as well (first timers). I've been researching and planning the trip for the past 4 weeks. I was stressing myself out worrying about transportation,
crime, excursions,wher
e to stay, etc. We decided to just book a Rome/Amalfi Coast 9 day tour. The tour company will take care of everything. I realize tours are not for everyone, but for us, this is the best option.
I liked amalfi, give positano a miss.

text:
Looking for any tips or advice… traveling from JFK to Rome on American Airlines with my daughters wedding gown . Has anyone carried a gown on? What’s the procedure? Only helpful comments very stressed mother of the bride here… PS called the airline and am always on hold forever …
Thank you in advance .

comments.comment_text: You can use it as your carry on. Pack it nicely

My daughter just got married in Italy. She flew from San Diego with a very large, poofy dress in a garment bag that was considered a carry on. Her husband did the same for his tux and shoes. My husband, younger daughter and I flew from Newark on United direct to Rome and then took 2 trains to Lucca. I did the same thing with our stuff. I fit my dress, my daughter’s MOH dress, my husband’s tux, all of our shoes, handbags, accessories, church programs, favors and menus in a garment bag. It weighed 25 pounds and was a pain to lug around but it was better than packing things in a checked bag that could have gotten lost. I figured that if our luggage was lost or delayed for some reason, at least we would all have our wedding outfits. 😆
It worked out just fine for all of us. There are no weight limits for carry ons and our garment bag fit in the overhead bin. I think they hung my daughter’s gown up for her in the captains closet.
We both called ahead of time just to make sure we did everything correctly.
I think most airlines go out of their way to try and accommodate brides.
And when the wedding was over, we shipped everything back the next day bc there was no way we were going to be dragging around all that stuff for the rest of our travels.
Good luck!
I carried mine on to Costa Rica. I believe it was American.
Check the airline website. I have seen one or two give specific instructions for wedding dresses.
I carried my dress onboard & they put it in the Captains closet. They are so nice & wanted to help in every way.

I don't have an answer but I do have a question.....ar
e they doing a legal marriage in Italy, which I've heard is very complicated, or are they doing legal ceremony in the US and just a symbolic ceremony in Italy?

The roads are tight and ppl drive crazy. I drive in Italy (however, I’ve been coming here my entire life 2 months/year), and the way my butt cheeks clench sometimes…. & The whites of my knuckles showing the way I grip that steering wheel 😅

Do not drive. Narrow roads, on cliffs, buses near. Been there! Had a driver so we could enjoy the views a bit!!

My advise, don’t rent a car. I would not rent a car in Naples. Arrange a car service to pick u up from the Naples airport, by emailing your hotel for a transfer to Sorrento. text:
Question for those who love Cinque Terre... what do you love about it? Is it primarily the scenic photo ops or is there something deeper that draws you in? How do you spend your time after you take in theआणखी scene and snap the photo? As we are mapping out our itinerary, I'm really struggling with whether to include the riviera. I definitely want to include some beach time and I'm wrestling between CT (& surrounding areas), Elba or Procida/Ischia. I *think* my primary draw to CT is the beautiful landscapes. But all of Italy is so dang picturesque and alluring and so I'm trying very hard not to let this become an "instagram" experience... a checklist of one photogenic spot to the next. I want to really experience the life in each place we visit so we're trying to be selective. We plan to spend 4-5 days in each area we visit.

(Photo cred: misc. google photo)

comments.comment_text: Hiking
For beaches Ischia

CT is my all-time happy place. There are so many factors, but yes, the instant “wow” when you first catch a glimpse is there for sure. It still takes my breath away and we have visited four times. It used to be not so crazy busy, but like anywhere beautiful, when the secret is out people come from all over. If you stay in a village you are able to capture the essence of CT, once all the day trippers go home. It is laid back, yet beautiful, relaxed yet classy, steeped in history, stunningly picturesque and oh so magical… and the coastal walk is bucket list stuff. It’s perfectly unique in every way, you will not regret staying in CT, particularly Vernazza (my fave).
Having said all that, we spent 5 days in Ischia about 5 years ago and absolutely loved it! Swings and roundabouts, but you will be happy with either. We did Procida as a day trip from Oschia and it’s pretty but much smaller, I think I would have got bored there.
Hike from town to town, enjoy the CT wines, eat the seafood( esp the fried cone of seafood) and take a boat ride. Gorgeous scenery.

I’ve been twice to CT and love it. First time stayed 3 nights, then 5. I would never recommend just doing a day trip, as it gets swarmed with tour boats and the experience IMO would be very negative. The locals told us that this swarm buy very little, patronize very little, make it hard on their infrastructure,
washrooms etc, add to the shoplifting concerns etc etc. What we did, and had the greatest experience, was enjoy coffee and croissant in the piazza in the morning, watching all the store owners prepping for the day, hosing down the cobblestone, setting up tables, putting out merchandise. Then we went to a local deli to buy lunches for hiking. Then we would decide where to hike for the day. We would be hiking during the crazy busy tourist part of the day, thus avoiding the crowds. Then by late afternoon we would go back to our local accommodations,
rest, then when the crowds had thinned we would go through some shops, go to the beach, then out for dinner. I would love to spend a month in CT, but only if I could live like a local

When we go we spend 6 weeks in cinque Terre. The whole coast line has beautiful vistas and wonderful people. Riomaggiore and Monterosso is our favourite.
Take a short bus ride from LaSpezia and see portovenere
Tellaro,oh! And Bonassola, so cute, pebble beach! Rapallo, go on the Funovia, don’t eat at the first restaurant you see, keep going up the mountain, it’s a short walk thru a beautiful treed area, moss covered trees and glimpses of outstanding vistas. You’ll find a delightful restaurant covered by climbing roses. The owners are son and mom. We had such a wonderful conversation with him! Hubby calls him ‘papa zen’ to this day. Portofino, CAMOGLI. Don’t let others sway you negatively. It’s gorgeous ! Busy, yup. We try and go early spring or when school goes back. Whatever. I wouldn’t miss it for the world ! Monterosso, try the seafood risotto at Ciac, mouthwatering!
Riomaggiore, sit on the edge of a cliff and enjoy the sea at Pie de Ma
Later when you need another snack try Tutti Friti
Say hi to the sea for me!
Can u just imagine living there😍
The draw was the invitation to slow down.
The hiking trails to all 5 towns is breathtaking and if you’re not able to walk that distance I believe there is a train that follows a similar route.
Krasen Kris
My fiancé (now husband) and I were there in 2002. We stayed in vernazza in a little pensione above the town square. It was magical. So beautiful and quaint. We absolutely loved it. 💙🙌🏽
Just beautiful!!!♥️♥️
We loved Porto Venere..a true Gem.
The food is so good there! Best calamari just from the take out shops, focaccia originated here and is amazing. Also pesto, so fresh & delicious.

My family and I just got back from staying in Manarola. I took the instagram shot, yes, but my favorite moments were photographing the town in the quiet of the morning before the crowds came (just me and the cats) and a late afternoon soak in the warm Ligurian Sea, literally a jump off of the rock.
The views, the hiking, the beach, the food - all amazing, but my favorite part was sitting up on our rooftop patio overlooking the town square with the beach in the distance. Beautiful

I’m coming to CT and want to stay for one night with 3 teenagers. Does anyone have a recommendation of where to stay that’s not really expensive? We want to spend the big money on the doing and the food!

I’m in Monterosso at the moment. Yes there are lots of people and I’m not a fan of crowds, but I still love it here. The food is to die for. It’s easy to get around and just sitting back and enjoying the culture.

Took a hiking trip to the Cinque Terre, and it was my favorite adventure ever. Had two very knowledgeable guides, we explored places you can only get by hiking, talked to and ate meals with the people who lived there, really immersed ourselves completely. It was an incredible experience that is still vivid nearly 20 years later.
Everything! The scenery, the hiking, the beach/ swimming, the food, exploring each town and experiencing the culture. 🍷

This past May we hiked from Monterosso to Vernazza (would have gone farther but we started late). It was an amazing and challenging hike. The views were breathtaking. We ended by having dinner in Vernazza at sunset. Would do it again in a heartbeat
I fell in love with Elba.
Calabria, Puglia, everytime for me
I stayed here. Very nice and moderately priced. Easy walk to train/port. Right in old town.
Everything the weather the food the people the scenery and the warm water of the mar the Liguria Bella Italia

If you like beaches then go to Elba and rent a motorbike/
moped/scooter. Thank me later!
Following
Joanne Dorn

We went last year and again last week . I suggest for the photo op and shopping Vernazza . Monterosso is my favorite for the beach CT experience . Btw we stayed in Sestri Levante which is really nice so is Levanto also ..

I’m clearly an outlier with my thoughts on Cinque Terre. I was there very end of September last year. First the great….we stayed at a FANTASTIC Airbnb outside of Riomaggiore. It was a farm stay and breakfast, evening meals, delicious wines and piano playing included. It was serene. The hike through the ancient vineyards to Riomaggiore was amazing. That alone was worth the stay. Now the not so great… I thought the small towns were absolutely packed with people, the trains…absolute
ly packed with people, and the food subpar. Even the gelato was some of the worst that we had in Italy. Clearly everything was geared simply towards tourism. People were lovely and nice, but that was about it. ￼We pushed our way through the cute streets with hordes of other tourists ￼, and shuffled around, trying to catch glimpses of what should have been a beautiful visit. Keeping in mind, this was the end of September, and on somewhat rainier days. I can’t even imagine what it would’ve been like during peak season. The ferry boats weren’t running either because it was windy. The one day spent in Monterosso was more enjoyable because there’s more room to spread out. ￼Although I would love to go back to that Airbnb…I would never go back to Cinque Terre￼.

I love it. Each village has its own personality. Great food. Hikes. In Summer you can take s boat from village to village. In off season you take the trains. As others have said… stay a couple of nights because it’s the mornings and evenings that are loveliest after day trippers are gone. We stayed in Vernazza once and Monterosso once. Vernazza was my favorite. CT is wonderful just to soak in. ♥️

I was there in 1989 and it was magical. That was the only word to describe the Cinque Terre. We stayed in a youth hostel called Mama Rosa's and it was run by a magical being called Rosa. She did not speak any English, there was no Google or anything at that time. We communicated with our hands, feet and facial expressions. Every night there was a feast. Mama would make the pasta and the other guests would all bring stuff to contribute. It was a memory that I still hold close to my heart. Now it us over run with tourists and ofcourse that completely changes everything. Having said that , if you go anywhere in the hight of tourist season you will have huge crowds. This year being the highest ever for Italy. I choose to travel to Europe in the shoulder season May or Sept, Oct to avoid this. Cinque Terre will always be one if my favorite places on earth and it is not true that Italians do not live there, they do and we as tourists need to respect that.
We took a boat tour from La Spezia. Saw all 5 stopped for a few hours each at two. Wouldn’t want to have missed that great day.
Love this post. It’s not all about the perfect shot.
Do a guided hike- it was rigorous and amazing- my favorite experience of my month-long trip in Italy.

What I loved most the first time I was there (2009) was the concept: the Italian government made the area a National Park. It (more or less) maintains the hiking paths along the coastline and up the hillsides. If you owned a home, store, etc., it was still yours, but the ground under your feet was under national preservation. There is a Marine Protected Area. The hillsides were terraced and planted with lemon trees and grape vineyards. Co-ops were created to sell local wine, lemoncello, produce and cosmetics made of local herbs and lemon. No cars allowed. Little natural-gas powered buses free for seniors. Perfect? No. Nirvana. Probably not. And yet a wonderful idea that mostly works.
How do I get from town to town. Hike or are there taxis
It was our family’s favorite part of Italy!

Cinque Terra is an experience. My fav of all Italian cities we visited. Keep in mind, we like to learn of different cultures and ways of life around the globe. I very vividly remember and talk about CT over 15 years later. We had our children, age 8 and 11, and purposefully immersed ourselves in the communities. Instead of racing from village to village and just getting those once in a lifetime videos and photos, we talked to the shop owners and residents, were invited to Bocce ball in the park where the whole village comes out in the evening to socialize, got to know a lot about our host at the B n B and their 'way of life'. We even found a family there with children and left a backpack with a 'traveling' bear and a journal for them to write in and pass on to other foreigners. (We received it back years later with some entries from Italian families...) The people were lovely. I hope it is still the same because we do plan to return. Go off season!!!!

I spent 5 days in LaSpezia, traveling to CT daily by boat or train. One of the nights we stayed in Monterosso Al mare (spur of the moment-double booked with our LaSpezia hotel), which gave us a glimpse of CT Italian life after many daytime tourists left for the day. We hiked between all the villages, which was amazing! Wandered the streets and paths until midnight, enjoying the families strolling together. I loved it so much I went there again a few years later for just one night. Next time I’d like 3-5 days again. CT is very special.

Interesting comments and some good info. Thanks!
We’re planning a week there in October—-we like slow travel—not remotely worried about finding “things to do.” Just hanging out, hiking, exploring….

I felt the same, so dropped from my list. This may be a good photo spot and scenery.what else ? I’ve been in Italy for 15 days in June..and and ..one city that really touched me and I got attached was ROME..you have everything in here..for some reason most of the friends here does not recommend more than 3 days in Rome..Rome is a place where you can stick around for weeks and still not get bored ..my personal opinion and favourite

We stayed in Rapallo for a few days and absolutely loved it! It was in the beginning of June so it didn't seem crowded to us at that time. And it seems to be a place where Europeans vacation to relax versus going just to get pictures. And it's stunningly gorgeous! So we took a day trip to visit Cinque Terre from Rapallo. Some of it was really great, but overall very touristy and crowded, and if you get car sick, the windy roads are a recipe for motion sickness. Not to take away from its beauty though. It's seriously is gorgeous.

We stay in an Airbnb about a block from the beach. I can hear the bread man drive up at 6am in the morning, the cafe workers sweeping the streets and getting ready for the day, the church bells chiming and then I take a walk as the town is waking up - I love it there and going back for the 3rd time next month — the water, the food, the hospitality are all amazing - and I go to Italy frequently and try to work 5T in each time — love ❤️

I have not been yet(will be in CT for 4 nights in September)
It was the first spot I put on my Italy Itinerary. The allure was the gorgeous looking coastline and hiking trails. I also had wanted to visit Elba but it was nixed from our list but we will be visiting Ischia and maybe Procida

Love all of Italy but Vernazza holds a special place in my heart and I go back every time I visit Italy.
Walking the villages (Vernazza to monterosso is the best direction to hike and then train back) don’t need to hike them all if not into hiking. Exploring the coast by boat and train. Getting a ferry down to Portovenere is a must.

My favourite is having coffee in the piazza before the day trippers arrive, or the pastries at Il Pirata up past the train station before they sell out because they are so good, and then dinner and drinks once everyone has gone. Aperitivo time is busy but we always found a table. Just magic.

The locals come out and catch up in the piazza, the shop owners got to know us and would give my daughter strawberries or something extra for desert. Pace slows right down and that’s when you feel it, the place has a lovely energy to it you can feel.

Being out and about exploring during the day but coming back once everyone had gone worked for us.

Our last visit was June 2018 and we are due to go back next July. Will be interesting to see how I find it as I hear the number or cruise ships docking at La Spezia has increased. Am hoping for the same plan - to enjoy the energy of the place in the morning and late arvo into the evening. (Avoiding lunch!!)

We just got back from the and we went for the pictures and sunset and to swim in the cool coves.Manarola was our fav bc kids jumped off rocks, Vernazza was similar but not as intense and Monterosso was just gorgeous turquoise waters w fun waves....Riomag
giore was a breathing view but swimming was better at the others. Manarola had both... We also went to Boccadesse in Genoa and Tirrenia in Pisa...all amazing

However be very aware as they are unforgiving if you don't have the right train ticket or drive in the wrong place. We received hefty fines that had to be paid on the spot but it was still well worth it
Beach time, unique beaches from one town to the next, hiking, enjoying slow Italian life in each town (dolce far niente!)

This is a great post, a great question, and it has prompted me to reconsider my travel plans and motive for visiting CT.

A question for those who have said CT villages are very pleasant in the mornings and evenings when daytrippers have gone - what do you do in the middle of the day? Once you've done your hiking and taken your picturesque photos each morning and evening, what else do you do there?

I'd imagine it would be difficult to escape the crowds during the day. I feel like I'd be wasting many hours waiting for daytrippers to leave just so I can enjoy a few quieter hours later in the day.

Considering this, the experience of spending full days in quieter, authentic Tuscan villages sipping wine and soaking up the Italian culture feels so much more appealing.

I was just there last week. We spent 3 nights. We stayed at La Spezia and took the train every day to visit the villages. We absolutely loved. I did one day at the beach where we rented chairs. Had a great beach day. My favorite village was Monterosso.

Sad thing about the Cique Terre is that it’s such a gem but overrun by tourism now more than ever. The towns are so tiny and not built to have full capacity at all hotels but that is the situation these days. As a result these quaint fishing villages where are truly some of the most magical places in all of Italy are just not what they used to be. I wish I had advice but unfort I just wanted to share this observation. The “revenge travel” situation that is happening is so rough.
Nauman Khan
It’s gorgeous! The ocean, the buildings, the beach, all of it. It’s was our fave part of our trip.
Tenniel McKenzie
Kasia Green

As with everything else in life, I believe you have to go and then decide for yourself how it was and what it meant for you. I suggest you go for a couple days and then you’ll have your own thoughts and memories. We have been to many places in Italy, and were in Cinque ￼Terre last September and loved every minute of it. After the photo op, just sitting on the waters edge, talking to people from around the world, eating wonderful food, taking a swim and then watching the sunset is tough to beat. Also, all 5 towns are very close together and offer specialties to each of them. Good luck with your decision and consider it doesn’t really matter what anyone else’s experience may have been for them. Only your experience is going to matter in the end. Hope that helps. ￼

I spent 3 nights in Cinque Terre. I enjoyed it and was glad I went, but I honestly thought that it’s the only place I’ve ever visited that’s more beautiful in pictures than it is in real life. I prefer the Amalfi Coast. That’s much more beautiful than Cinque Terre in my opinion.
I love the Cinque Terre for the photo ops. My husband and I are amateur photographers and love places that are scenic and photo worthy and the CT definitely meets that criteria.

I experienced CT before being “discovered”. Truly magical towns! If you like to see real Italy, perhaps the Puglia region, or Matera! Hidden gems, I must say. Or Ortygia in Sicily. Of course, if you go at the height of the season anywhere, you may not be able to find what you’re looking for! Buon viaje!

I spent the time taking in the scenery. Sitting with a glass of wine and soaking it all in. Watching how the building change colour as the light changes, what the people are doing, all the small things. It’s the Italian art of doing nothing while soaking in beauty. More than just snapping the photo. It’s imprinting it in your memory for years to come.

That's a good question! I haven't been there yet, so I look forward to some responses.I felt like the Amalfi coast was sort of a check list stop for us, and found it very disappointing. I enjoyed Polignano a Mare much more.

Ischia was nice (enjoyed the castle and the town). I wish had more time there because our all day boat trip around the island was canceled due to high swells. People seem to enjoy the spas there, but I'm not a spa person.

I don't think I had as much of an emotional response to cinque Terre as I did florence and siena but I definitely had a lot moments where my breath was taken away because of the scenery. And there were a lot of memorable experiences as well from pesto making class to just sitting on the rocky beach in Riomaggiore enjoying the waves and watching people surf. Also we had a rooftop patio that was perfect at the end of the night with beautiful views.

The whole thing is wondering about how life was there in the past, how the people lived, and hard work terracing and cultivating on the steep mountain sides. Bear in mind that Cinque Terre had no road until the 1970's.
It's a place to enjoy spectacular scenery, hike and be grateful we hike and go there for pleasure. To marvel at the resilience to life.

Mainly the scenery but there are lovely restaurants. The beach at Monterosso is great to spend the day. The walks between the towns are an adventure. Lots of shops. The scenery is definitely worth the visit though. You can see all the towns in one day though if you need to.

Um. I think if anyone travels anywhere just to take a photo, that's a sad existence.
CT has the same values as any destination: history, culture, food, enjoyment in the way the people live, hiking, scenery.
Swim, eat, hike, learn, shop, relax

I debated back and forth about going, but was drawn because of the beautiful photos of it I’d seen. I opted for a day trip from Florence just to get a taste, spent a little time at 4 out of 5. Yes, I did get all the beautiful photos I wanted, but experienced the scenery and though similar how each land had a different vibe to it. Part of my trip to Italy, as with many places I visit, is to see and experience beautiful things and places. I’m so glad I went even if it was brief.

The swimming was my favourite part! Especially in Riomaggiore and Monterosso Al Mare. Being in the water and looking back at the towns was magical. And also the hikes between towns of course. We had 3 full days there but I left wishing that we had done a full day in each town as it was so hard to leave each of the beaches/
swimming areas and move onto the 2nd town of the day!
Hiking town to town was our highlight. It was moderate to difficult hike. Beyond that, beautiful scenery but you can find scenery all over Italy.
Vast majority of the shop owners don't live there. They only come during tourist season and have another place of residence so to speak from what I was told.
Walking through each village to the next gives you a deeper feeling for the area. Just getting on a boat and taking a photo doesn’t do it for me.

Pros: We had perfect fall weather, and we hiked as much as you can hike. Some cute restaurants. Great views. Uniquely situated towns. Cons: Crowds especially in narrow streets of Vernazza. Our first visit there years earlier was a drive down to Vernazza. Nobody there. Nice picnic, and the last time we pretty much avoided it. Even Portofino (pictured) and Porto Venere not as crowded. We loved Rapallo (where we based for a week), Santa Margarita Ligure and Camogli. Rail trip to Genoa also worthwhile.
Swimming!
We were just in Italy for two weeks and personally we decided to skip it. ￼ We figured it was one of those “save it for later things “ like when we were old and on a cruise ship.

We were there 2.5 days and I could have stayed longer! Mornings and evenings were magical! Days can get crowded with day trippers. I liked the smaller town and the beach vibe. We did a great private boat tour with Simone!!
I was in Cinque Terre a good 15 years ago. I loved it because, besides the beautiful scenery and hiking, it was easy to see everyday life. CT felt authentic.
For me, had I had just gone in the day, I wouldn’t have felt the same. But staying there, when the crowds ease up and the calm returns at dusk, it’s just kind of magical. Going again next May.

Agree with the swimming and hiking comments above. Also loved enjoying the towns after the day-trippers left. That said, I've also heard amazing things about the islands you mentioned, so I don't think you can make a wrong decision
Ischia is quieter and there are bigger beaches - it has the stunning landscape but not as concentrated . I did not Cinque Terre and ischia - loved both
We just went for the first time and loved it. Stayed in Vernazza and it was out favourite, followed by Corniglia. Monterosso was our least favourite felt like it didn’t belong.

Unfortunately all travel and photos taken seem to be for those Instagram photos , snap the photo and rush off to the next area. Take Trevi fountain as an example, hundreds of people daily for the perfect pose and photo, but do people really know the history behind it? 😬
CT is stunning, the beauty, hiking from village to village, the ocean, taking it all in. Definitely worth a visit ☀️👍🇮🇹
I love the fishing town vibe, the hiking, and the food and wine.

If your interest is in beaches and “sea-life”, I think Elba or Procida or Ischia are much better.
Cinque Terre are amazing (very picturesque, as you said, and also the sea is beautiful), but beaches are very very little and consequently crowded, so you cannot enjoy them very much.
I think the most beautiful thing in Cinque Terre is the trekking you can go through them, but it’s pretty hard (really a lot of up and down)
La Spezia is great my personal favorite been three times and easy to take the train to Cinque if you want
I HIGHLY recommend Ischia. Gorgeous views, great food, hot springs.. shopping .. i can go on and on. Spent four days there in April and can’t wait to go back
We hv the same predicament. Thank u for sharing🩷🌼☀️
Do i need to walk a lot of stairs in CT? Im 71 and just being careful😊
We are in the same situation …. Was originally planning to end our Italy trip in CT but have charged course for similar reasons you mention. I’m now leaning toward Elba

I was just in the Italian riviera. We stayed in Genova and loved it. Friends who live near Genova advised us to skip the Cinque Terre and instead visit some of the other small towns along the coast. We hired a private boat with captain and visited Camogli and San fruttuoso. We went swimming from the boat. We enjoyed the views. Had some sun and water time and skipped the crowded beaches. The Cinque Terre are charming but so are many other towns. ( I visited the cinque terre years ago)

We’ve just done 5 weeks in Europe and spent 5 glorious days in Monterosso (last week). It was a great way to chill out after being so busy touring everywhere. We sat at the beach all day then explored the towns in the evening. Atm, the sun doesn’t go down till around 9.30pm so we would get to each town around 6.30ish, have dinner then explore. It was way cooler doing it this way, the heat was just too unbearable otherwise.

Hiking thru to all the towns.
Beautiful scenery.

text:
Okay guy, I’m asking a lot here, but we leave for Venice in 2 weeks and will be there for 2 days. We have a professional photographer taking pics to help us remember the experience.

Looking for an experience on asking for recommendations on shopping, water taxis, can you buy tickets for the Duomo the day of or need to buy in advance, Doges palace a must see, etc… if you could do it again, what would you recommend? And go..

Just got back from a trip of a lifetime.
One tour we did was worth mentioning.
We did the lemon tour in Amalfi. 🍋 We did a private 8 person tour with lunch. We ate lemons whole, rind and all, put on bee keeper suits, ate fresh honey. It was an amazing experience.

Hi everyone 👋
I wondered if you had a good suggestion for a sit down restaurant in Naples. Maybe one that plays music or has entertainment. 😊 thanks! We will be there mid-September
How angry to restaurants get if you ask for your dish without cheese?

comments.comment_text: We were in Florence and didn’t ask for cheese - the waitstaff asked us if we wanted it. The couple times my husband asked - well no one rolled their eyes in front of us- maybe they did in the kitchen 😂 we loved every restaurant we went to and had great service all around.

In Italy, if you order pasta, the cheese is put on the table and you add it yourself.
It won't come out of the kitchen with cheese on it.
I accidentally ordered pizza without cheese!! They made it without complaint! I was just taken aback by MY mistake and laughed at myself and understood why the server looked puzzled 😂😂😂
Way would they get angry?
Honestly some people ask silly questions. Any restaurant you go will accommodate your taste bud .
I’m dairy free and ask for it at every meal just to make sure and it’s never been an issue!!
I can’t believe this is even a post lol
Luckily for us the restaurants are seeking profits and should therefore want to accommodate the requests of people wanting to pay them money

The Italian Cheese God will throw a hissy fit and cause thunder and lightening to follow you wherever you go. For the rest of your entire life !. Seriously...my kids are Italian and never eat cheese. Its not written in the constiution that you have to eat cheese.
Steve Dobson 🤣

text:
If you are in CInque Terre or nearby - I can't recommend this tour enough - Ebikein-Cinque Terre https://www.ebikein-cinqueterre.it/ with Matteo This was our favorite tour we did (kids 15 and 12) and was the perfect way to avoid the crowds - Don't miss the e-bike experience in the stunning on the Ligurian Riviera, at a short distance to the famous Cinque Terre, and I cannot recommend it enough! Exploring the picturesque villages of Framura, Bonassola, Costa on e-bikes was our families favorite activity in our 2 weeks in Italy, and it added a whole new dimension to our trip. First and foremost, the e-bikes provided by the tour company were top-notch. They were comfortable, well-maintained, and incredibly easy to use, making them suitable for all fitness levels and ages. The electric assist was a game-changer, allowing us to effortlessly pedal along the hilly terrain while soaking in the breathtaking views of the Italian Riviera. The local guide Sara was incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about Cinque Terre, which truly enhanced our experience. They shared fascinating stories about the history, culture, and traditions of the region, making each stop along the way even more meaningful. Did I mention the VIEWS! You finish in Levanto and you can stop at the award winning @https://www.facebook.com/pizzerialapicea which was the best pizza we had in Italy (we went 2 times) - Get the La Gola!
— Ebikein Cinque Terre येथे.

text: Can’t decide guided tour (trafalgar) or self tour. We are in our early 70,s and still very active. Concerned about self travel between cities. Want to tour Florence, Venice, Rome and Amaffi Coast. Suggestions?

comments.comment_text: We just did a tour for first time with my family of 7. It was the best thing as we got to see so much in a short amount of time without the hassle of planning, transfers between cities and lugging luggage! It worked very well for us. We got to sit and enjoy! Of course it comes with a price and some cons. Enjoy your trip!

We planned a self tour with the help of travel agent. They booked transportation for us in between the cities we visited which made it super easy without the confines of a large guided tour to worry about.
For safety, ease of travel, & peace of mind- I’d say go with a tour.
My first trip to Italy was with a tour. The tour landed in Naples(Amalfi Coast) and ended in Venice. It was the trip of a lifetime!
Couldn't pay me enough to go on a group tour!

Look at a pre planned tour then use that as a guide for your self tour -
Those cities have great train services and widely visited by this group -
Use rRone to rio or Omio app for trains bookings or eurorail
Use this site to find useful info that others have used in their trip eg Vatican official site to book tours
If u want to see something specific make sure the site is open in the days u r there
It’s not too hard just a bit of your time to jot notes down n places if interest to see
I’m doing my second self visit planning as a senior and taking 4 others with me
Try it it’s not that scary ☺️
Ps we are taking Backpacks 40llts and less so don’t have to carry suitcases & I have a terrible spinal issues ( dont have to fill it )
We do our own tours. The trains are wonderful! We are also in our 70's.
Our group of 10 senior ladies had a great self tour!!

I’m in my 70s, did it all by rail last year, Trainline app and a SIM card, very easy. Just pick places and accommodation on or near a trainline, luggage is the biggest problem, lugging suitcases around.
Traveling between Florence, ￼ Venice, Rome, and Naples is fast and easy using the high-speed trains. From Naples to the Amalfi Coast, you can take a private transfer or a ferry.
Train is fabulous – so easy.

The tour companies have good and not so good. They leave early in the mornings and expect your bags out by 7am sometimes. They are fast paced and sometimes a different hotel every night for part of the trip. Check their itinerary and put it out here or join a tour website to see. Having just done a bus tour, I would personally plan another trip. You can also arrange tour guides in individual places. I thought I would do the golf cart tour in Rome if I went again.
I used Globus Tours for 3 times and they are great!

Currently on Trafalgar Italian Concerto tour which visits those places. It has been nothing short of amazing. Everything is planned for you and there are optional tours that you can select. I am loving that guides gather our bags and we basically show up! It is probably a great deal more expensive than doing it all yourself but we are finding it very worth the cost!

If you are used to travel by yourself, you definitely can do it in Italy and probably will enjoy more!
Then you can take a guide for some historical site (I suggest you to do it, so you’ll have good and very interesting explanations about what you are seeing), you often find them at the entrance, or you can book some visit on specific websites as Get your Guide (I did like this in Colosseo and Fori Imperiali and it was good!)

If this is your first time traveling to Italy, I would suggest a tour. If you travel off season you will save thousands of dollars, and avoid the brutal heat of traveling in the summer-time. Gate 1 offers some reasonably priced tours and you can add go ahead and stay behind options. They also offered different hotel class and flight options which is a nice feature. We had a wonderful time traveling with them.

We just did a tour with Gate 1. We are in mid 70’s and didn’t want the hassle of managing luggage, making reservations, etc. Did all of that when we were younger, but find tours convenient now. Here’s where we went: Lake Como, Venice, Cinque Terre, Siena, Lucca, Florence, Positano, Amalfi, Capri ( my personal favorite), and Rome. It was a wonderful tour. They arranged local guides in many of the places we went in addition to our tour guide. Our bus was spic and span and we learned so much history along the way. The hotels we stayed at were very nice and many meals provided. There were some younger couples with us who often went out on their own so that possibility exists as well. The only downside is that you often have to have your luggage outside your hotel door early in the morning. BUT, we got started early and often avoided the big crowds. We stayed in one hotel 4 nights and another 3. Our tour was 14 days long. If you’re traveling to Italy for the first time, most hotels don’t provide wash cloths so go to Dollar Store and pick up some cheap ones. I just left them behind as we travelled.
Trafalgar, I have traveled to Italy twice with them and loved both tours

Guided tour is best and you do t have to worry about tickets or standing in line or anything. Get a travel agent that will take care of you. I took my 83 year old mom to Great Britain and the guided tour took care of her and she did not have to walk far or stand in the heat or wait

text: Booking our trip to Italy. Thoughts on travel insurance?

comments.comment_text: Allianz and Chase Sapphire Preferred credit card. I’ve had to make claims 3times and Allianz is the best.
Yes, Take it!

Don’t leave home without it! I broke my wrist in Italy last year, and my travel insurance covered all the expenses I incurred for medical bills and transportation to doctors and the hospital. They also have a 24/7 help line, and they helped me arrange transportation for my return trip to the airport. I couldn’t handle my luggage very well with a broken wrist, and they were going to provide my transport. Thankfully, my lovely Air B&B host arranged it for me, so I didn’t need the insurance provider’s help with that.

Don’t leave home without it!
As an insurance broker the theory is if you can’t afford the travel insurance you can’t afford the trip! You just never know and have the peace of mind for anything unforeseen. I have used mine for coming off of a scooter in Thailand, given first class home due to injuries, volcanic disruptions in Australia. My parents had to come home from a NZ cruise due to an unexpected death of a young family member. TID is good. Allianz is another one. Also World2cover. Underwritten by the same people that look after Accident & Health for corporate travel insurance. Make sure you get top cover as most of them now include some Covid cover. Safe travels.

text: Following on from the fun we had in Tuscany we decided to do the Rome 500 Exp’s Seven Hidden Gems tour. Our guide Alex ensured that we had a fun time and explored many spots on Rome that we would not haveआणखी otherwise. Unlike the Tuscany tour we were in communication via walkie talkie which was fun and entertaining. Highly recommend it and the kids had a blast waving at people as we drove through Rome. Navigating the streets of Trastevere was one of the highlights including being forced to back up an entire street which was not something I had experienced in Tuscany!

text:
Colosseum Night Tour (Luna) Experience!
First, we just got back from Italy and the last night we did this tour. You can either get tickets online directly from Coopculture when they become available 30 days in advance OR if you have a guide, any guide, they can call Coopculture in advance and reserve spots for you. There is additional availablity that you can't see online that are reserved for guides. Your guide does not come with you, it is done directly through the Colosseum, but for some reason, they are still able to reserve spots for clients. Once the guide reserves the ticket, you call Coopculture directly and pay for it. I don't know the number - you can look it up online.
Second, when our guide called to reserve, the only tickets left were in Italian. We got the 9:40 pm slot and when arrived and escorted to the tour area, the Colosseum guide came out and said "Let me guess, no one on this tour speaks Italian!" So, the entire tour was conducted in English. I guess it is very common at this point, so don't worry if you only can secure Italian tour tickets. It was great at night and not too hot either! Very worthwhile and took about an hour. Tickets cost us about $25 euro each.
